ecoregion: Subtropical vegetation, wetlands, pine forests, agricultural areas, increasing urbanization
method_dispersal:
on the eye, We defined independence and the start of dispersal as the first date that a juvenile panther was separated from its mother by at least one week. Dispersal was measured from the estimated moment of independence to (1) the first encounter with an adult male if the disperser was at least 18 months old and female (Maehr et al., 1989b) or if both animals remained together for >2 consecutive flights; (2) the death of the disperser if it preceded sexual activity; or (3) if the disperser exhibited six months of site fidelity suggestive of home range establishment. Effective dispersal was the distance
between the arithmetic home range center of the dispersing animal’s mother and the arithmetic home range center that resulted from the dispersal event. Maximum dispersal was the greatest distance that a dispersing panther was located from its natal range
areas_crossed: large river/channel, agricultural areas, paved highways,

method_dispersal: On the eye, First, we calculated the straight-line distance between the capture point and the last location we recorded

on the eye, Dispersal distances (straight line) were calculated from capture point to: site of death, last known location, or home-range center-point if the animal dispersed and successfully established a home-range. We considered a homerange successfully established when an animal resided in an area for >8 months post dispersal.

on the eye, Dispersal distances (straight line) were calculated from capture point to: site of death, last known location, or home-range center-point if the animal dispersed and successfully established a home-range. We considered a homerange successfully established when an animal resided in an area for >8 months post dispersal.
On the eye, Dispersal distance was measured as the Euclidean distance between a disperser’s origin/natal homerange and final dispersal location (home range or place of death).

(2015) proposed that localizing events lasting fewer than 20 d could result from a feeding bout of a transient individual, whereas events exceeding 20 d should indicate that a cougar has found enough resources to establish a permanent home range (HR) (i.e., to include the possibility of multiple kill events
